Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2015 IEEE Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (IEEE DySPAN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide support for students attending US universities to attend and present at the IEEE Conference on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (DySPAN) in Stockholm, Sweden from September 29 - October 2, 2015. IEEE DySPAN is the premier conference to discuss, publish and present recent advancements regarding technical and policy challenges in the spectrum domain. Conference participation is a crucial part of training students to be researchers but the cost can be prohibitive for many students. Given the scarcity of spectrum and importance to the US economy, it is essential to develop this pool of researchers.

Up to 16 students from US universities will have the opportunity to attend and present their work in this international forum through travel grants. Students from underrepresented groups will be especially encouraged to apply for the grants. Attending students will get feedback on their own research, learn about the state of the art and interact with a variety of senior researchers and peers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided travel support for twenty Ph.D. students attending US universities to attend and present their work at the 2015 IEEE Conference on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (DySPAN) held in Stockholm, Sweden from September 29 – October 2, 2015 and the 2017 IEEE DySPAN held in Baltimore, MD from March 6-9, 2017.  Ten Ph.D. students from eight different US universities were supported to attend  2015 IEEE DySPAN, including one underrepresented minority. Nine of the ten students presented their research at the conference. Ten students from nine different US universities were supported to attend 2017 IEEE DySPAN, including two underrepresented minorities.  Eight of the ten students presented their research at the conference.  IEEE DySPAN is the premier conference to discuss, publish and present recent advancements regarding technical and policy challenges in the spectrum domain. Conference participation is a crucial part of training students to be researchers but the cost can be prohibitive for many students. The travel grants enabled the attending students to get feedback on their own research, learn about the state of the art and interact with a variety of senior researchers and peers.  Given the scarcity of spectrum and importance to the US economy, it is essential to develop this pool of researchers.
